title: @SpringBootTest

answer.content:
It boots up the **entire Application Context** for integration testing.

It scans for `@SpringBootApplication`, starts the embedded server (if configured), and injects all beans, simulating a real running environment.

explanation: This is heavy and slow; use it for integration tests, not unit tests.

title: @MockBean
ques: When testing a Service, how do you mock its dependencies (like a Repository) so you don't hit the real database?

answer.content:
Use **`@MockBean`**.

This replaces the real bean in the Spring Context with a Mockito mock. You can then define its behavior (e.g., `when(repo.findById(1)).thenReturn(...)`).

explanation: It allows you to test the Service logic in isolation.

title: MockMvc
ques: What tool allows you to test Controllers without actually starting a full HTTP server?

answer.content:
**MockMvc**.

It allows you to send mock HTTP requests to your controllers and assert the response status, headers, and body content.

`mockMvc.perform(get("/users")).andExpect(status().isOk())`

title: DataJpaTest

answer.content:
It is a **slice test** for the Persistence Layer.

It configures an in-memory database (H2), scans for `@Entity` classes and Spring Data repositories, and **ignores** the Web layer (Controllers), making it much faster than `@SpringBootTest`.

explanation: Perfect for testing custom repository queries.
